image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: After a brief downturn earlier in the year, Australia's housing market is firmly in recovery mode, with CoreLogic data showing house prices increased for a sixth consecutive month in August.

title.children: House prices rise for sixth straight month, with interest rate outlook likely to see 'active' selling season

image.altText: A semi-trailer and a wrecked car covered with a tarpaulin on the side of a country road.

items.synopsis: Police say a B-double truck travelling north on the Hume collided with a car that was turning onto the freeway, killing all four people inside. The truck driver, 30, was taken to hospital with non life-threatening injuries.

title.children: Police investigate after four killed in truck, car collision in north-east Victoria

image.altText: Jetstar and Qantas planes next to each other on the tarmac at an airport.

items.synopsis: Qantas boss Alan Joyce has confirmed the airline and its subsidiary Jeststar have about $570 million in unclaimed credits. Here's how to figure out if you're owed a refund or how to redeem your credits.

title.children: Qantas and Jetstar are holding almost half a billion dollars in flight credits. Here's how to figure out what you're owed

image.altText: A row of solar panels and wind turbines

items.synopsis: AEMO's latest 10-year outlook is double-edged, foreshadowing both increased opportunities for generators and increased risks in terms of reliability — some sooner than others.

title.children: A cloud's just passed in front of Australia's electricity forecast — here's what it could mean

image.altText: A close up street view of an old Japanese house next to an apartment building.

items.synopsis: How does Tokyo's property market compare to Australia's? Here are four unique lessons, from loose zoning laws to smaller dwelling sizes, an advanced public transport system and an openness to development.

title.children: The four unique ways Tokyo approaches housing can offer lessons for Australia

image.altText: A person holds a Voice to Parliament official referendum booklet

items.synopsis: The Voice to Parliament campaign is already rife with misinformation. Here are some eyebrow-raising claims you may have seen about the referendum and how you can help ABC Investigations expose more like them.

title.children: Here are some falsehoods you're probably seeing about the Voice and what you can do about it

image.altText: Two men with greying hair in suits shake hands on a street watched by other people

items.synopsis: Australia's only Liberal premier is actively campaigning with a Labor prime minister for a Yes vote on a Voice to Parliament, while some of Tasmania's Aboriginal groups are hoping the No vote succeeds.

title.children: Australia's smallest state could play a bigger than usual part in the Voice referendum

image.altText: Eastern Metropolitan MP Matt Bach smiles in a garden.

items.synopsis: MP Matt Bach has quit politics to pursue a teaching career abroad, just days after he was mentioned in a defamation concerns notice.

title.children: Deputy upper house leader of Victorian Liberal Party quits parliament

image.altText: People on a street hold up signs protesting against the release of wastewater from the Fukushima nuclear plant.

items.synopsis: Japanese businesses and citizens living in China suffer a backlash following the release of treated radioactive wastewater from the damaged Fukushima nuclear power plant.

title.children: Japan started releasing treated nuclear wastewater from Fukushima into the Pacific. Reaction in China was swift

image.altText: A man with tattoos and sunglasses speaks into a microphone; Mitch Mcconnell stares at something offscreen

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Ex-Proud Boys leader gets 17 years over Capitol Riot, doctor says Mitch McConnell 'medically clear'. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
Rock band Dire Straits has paid tribute to its guitarist Jack Sonnie on Twitter, saying "Rest in Peace". The band Dire Straits Legacy, which Sonni was part of alongside musicians who recorded and toured with Dire Straits, paid tribute to the star on Facebook. "Our beloved Jack has left a void in our heart and soul … 
we will miss you so much, 
you are forever with us," the band said. Three days ago, Dire Straits Legacy shared with fans that Sonni would not be able to participate in upcoming gigs due to "health problems". The cause of his death has not been reported and a statement from his family has not been released.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dire Straits pays tribute to guitarist Jack Sonni

children.content: Rock band Dire Straits has paid tribute to its guitarist Jack Sonnie on Twitter, saying "Rest in Peace".
The band Dire Straits Legacy, which Sonni was part of alongside musicians who recorded and toured with Dire Straits, paid tribute to the star on Facebook.

"Our beloved Jack has left a void in our heart and soul … 
we will miss you so much, 
you are forever with us," the band said.
Three days ago, Dire Straits Legacy shared with fans that Sonni would not be able to participate in upcoming gigs due to "health problems".
The cause of his death has not been reported and a statement from his family has not been released.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ukraine has told critics of the pace of its three-month-old counteroffensive to "shut up". It's the sharpest signal yet of Kyiv's frustration at leaks from Western officials who say its forces are advancing too slowly. Since launching a much vaunted counteroffensive using many billions of dollars of Western military equipment, Ukraine has recaptured more than a dozen villages but has yet to penetrate Russia's main defences. Ukrainian commanders say they are moving slowly on purpose, degrading Russia's defences and logistics to reduce losses when they finally attack at full strength. Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba told reporters criticising the counter-offensive's pace equalled "spitting into the face of [the] Ukrainian soldier who sacrifices his life every day". "I would recommend all critics to shut up, come to Ukraine and try to liberate one square centimetre by themselves," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ukraine's Foreign Minister tells critics: 'Shut up'

children.content: Ukraine has told critics of the pace of its three-month-old counteroffensive to "shut up".
It's the sharpest signal yet of Kyiv's frustration at leaks from Western officials who say its forces are advancing too slowly.

Since launching a much vaunted counteroffensive using many billions of dollars of Western military equipment, Ukraine has recaptured more than a dozen villages but has yet to penetrate Russia's main defences.
Ukrainian commanders say they are moving slowly on purpose, degrading Russia's defences and logistics to reduce losses when they finally attack at full strength.
Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba told reporters criticising the counter-offensive's pace equalled "spitting into the face of [the] Ukrainian soldier who sacrifices his life every day".

props.alt: Ukraine's Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba speaks to the media

children.content: Dmytro Kuleba.
(Reuters: Isabel Infantes )
"I would recommend all critics to shut up, come to Ukraine and try to liberate one square centimetre by themselves," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Idalia has weakened further into a post tropical storm as it moved away from the US coast, according to the US National Hurricane Center. It has issued a tropical storm watch for Bermuda. The storm was about 265km south-east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, packing maximum sustained winds of 100kph, the NHC said. Meanwhile, in Florida the clean-up effort from the hurricane is underway, with photos showing the impact it has had.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Idalia weakens, clean-up effort begins in Florida

children.content: Idalia has weakened further into a post tropical storm as it moved away from the US coast, according to the US National Hurricane Center.
It has issued a tropical storm watch for Bermuda.
The storm was about 265km south-east of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, packing maximum sustained winds of 100kph, the NHC said.
Meanwhile, in Florida the clean-up effort from the hurricane is underway, with photos showing the impact it has had.
A damaged property in Horseshoe Beach, Florida.
(Reuters: Julio Cesar Chavez)
A shrimp business destroyed by Hurricane Idalia in Horseshoe Beach.
(Reuters: Julio Cesar Chavez)
A damaged property after the arrival of Hurricane Idalia in Horseshoe Beach.
(Reuters: Julio Cesar Chavez)

image.altText: Australiam Army soldiers stand at attention during an Anzac Day parade

items.synopsis: Hundreds of soldiers could be moved out of South Australia under a planned restructure of the army, with the Department of Defence considering options on how best to transform the service for future "littoral" operations.

title.children: Army considers removing Adelaide-based units

image.altText: Close up shot of Anthony Albanese.

items.synopsis: Thank goodness for Senate committees. This week, they've proved, yet again, to be worth their weight in accountability gold, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Thank goodness for Senate committees: They shed light on government secrets

image.altText: An aerial image shows a volcanic island emitting white smoke surrounded by clear blue sea on a clear day.

items.synopsis: James, Andrew and Peter Buttle apply to have the charges they are facing over the deadly 2019 eruption of their volcano dismissed.

title.children: Brothers who inherited NZ volcano ask judge to drop charges, claiming 'this is not a prosecution of a family'

image.altText: An illustration of a person's hand placing a ballot paper into a ballot box held by someone else's outstretched hands.

items.synopsis: For hundreds of thousands of Australians voting in the referendum on a Voice to Parliament, their votes will count differently to others. Here's why.

title.children: How some votes will be worth less than others in the upcoming referendum

image.altText: A mushroom with a split down the centre popping up through the gravel cement

items.synopsis: A photography exhibition in Manjimup, Western Australia, helps highlight the ecological importance of what some say is a forgotten part of the planet's biodiversity.

title.children: This award-winning photo isn't of a dragon's eye — it's a fungus growing through concrete

image.altText: Don and Gail, dressed in warm jackets, smile as they stand in front of the sea on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: The town of Korumburra in Victoria's south-east has come together to celebrate the life of Don and Gail Patterson, who police believe died from mushroom poisoning at a family lunch in July.

title.children: 'Lots of love to you all': Suspected mushroom poisoning victim's text to family revealed at memorial service

image.altText: Donald Trump, in suit, speaks with reporters in front of a plane that has his name on it.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump pleads not guilty to a wide-ranging Georgia criminal indictment related to his attempts to overturn his 2020 election defeat.

title.children: Trump pleads not guilty in Georgia election fraud case

image.altText: A man wearing a suit brings his hands to prayer position in front of his face

items.synopsis: Thaksin, Thailand's most famous politician, returned to his country last week after spending 15 years in self-imposed exile. Upon his arrival he was taken to prison to serve an eight-year sentence for abuse of power and conflicts of interest.

title.children: Thailand's billionaire ex-prime minister requests royal pardon after 15 years in exile

image.altText: Boy with cuts on his face and bruising on his eyes

items.synopsis: An investigation is underway after a six-year-old boy was allegedly bitten by a support dog at his South Coast school, with reports he was attempting to give the labradoodle a cuddle.

title.children: Year 1 student recovering after support dog allegedly bites his face at school

image.altText: A large ladder reaches at the top of the building with a firefighter in front of it

items.synopsis: One of the deadliest fires in South Africa leads to more than 74 deaths and scores of injuries, according to emergency services.

title.children: 'Sad day for the city of Johannesburg': More than 70 dead in building blaze

image.altText: Close up of Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce speaking to the media at a press event.

items.synopsis: Qantas has confirmed it will refund $570 million worth of COVID travel credits for domestic and international customers, while the ACCC has accused the airline of selling tickets for flights it had already cancelled.

title.children: 'People lost faith in the process': Qantas scraps expiry dates on $570m worth of COVID travel credits

image.altText: Chris Bowen in a navy suit and tie in front of the Australian flag at a press conference.

items.synopsis: Chris Bowen's comments follow warnings from the Australian Energy Market Operator that a hot and dry summer will put Victoria and South Australia at "elevated" risk of blackouts.

title.children: Energy minister says federal government wants power grid 'as stable as it possibly can be'

image.altText: Aerial photo showing a series of arrays of mirrors arranged in semi-circles facing individual towers

items.synopsis: Renewable energy company RayGen has officially opened its $27 million solar and thermal power plant project, in north-west Victoria.

title.children: These solar energy modules generate enough heat to melt metal. It's hoped they can help solve renewable storage issues

image.altText: The 18 AFLW captains for 2023 are pictured at Marvel Stadium. Kate Hore is standing in the centre with the Premiership Cup

items.synopsis: With another season of AFLW starting tonight, Kate O'Halloran explains where to watch, how to buy tickets, and what's new this year, including the big names to change clubs.

title.children: Want more women's sport now the Matildas' run is over? Here's all you need to know about AFLW season eight

items.synopsis: NSW beekeepers have launched a class action over loss of business after their hives were destroyed to curb the spread of varroa mite.

title.children: Beekeepers start class action against the NSW government over varroa mite efforts

image.altText: Telstra payphones in Birdsville

items.synopsis: When this outback business owner's telecommunications service cut out 10 times in a day, she says even Telstra staff suggested she switch to an alternative internet provider.

title.children: Bush residents ditching Telstra amid claims outback services are only 'getting worse'

image.altText: A food delivery rider on a bicycle with a crowd of people in the distance.

items.synopsis: The workplace minister says a small increase to the cost of pizza deliveries is "a small price to pay" to ensure gig workers are safe, as the government unveils its plan for minimum rates of pay for workers earning income through apps such as Uber and DoorDash.

title.children: New minimum pay rates for gig workers worth 'small increase' to pizza prices, says minister

image.altText: An drilling machine on a lake, blue sky with clouds, a drill in themiddle and two small boats on the side.

items.synopsis: A review of Gold Fields, which runs four mines in Australia,  has found that 47 per cent of its global workforce had experienced some form of inappropriate behaviour at work.

title.children: Global gold giant apologises for 'distressing' findings of widespread sexual harassment and bullying

image.altText: A woman embraces a soldier as she celebrates in Gabon.

items.synopsis: If successful, the coup attempt in Gabon will be the eighth one since 2020 in West and Central Africa, a region that in the past decade had made strides to shed its reputation as a "coup belt".

title.children: Gabon the latest nation in West and Central Africa to undergo a coup d'état. Here's what's gone down since 2020

image.altText: A young woman smiling

items.synopsis: Bailey Camilleri streamed The Big Bang Theory for about 10 minutes before his truck crashed into a car, killing Gemma Thompson just two weeks before her wedding.

title.children: Jail for truck driver who streamed sitcom on his phone before crash that killed Sydney teacher

image.altText: Ryan Papenhuyzen runs towards Sualauvi Faalogo who is on the floor, with his hands outstretched

items.synopsis: Brisbane miss out on the chance to seal the NRL minor premiership as Melbourne records a 14th-straight win over the Broncos at Lang Park as the second-string step up for the Storm.

title.children: 'Bitterly disappointing': Broncos miss chance to seal NRL minor premiership as Storm hoodoo remains

image.altText: A composite image showing rock singer Jimmy Barnes, politician Clive Palmer and rapper Eminem.

items.synopsis: Rapper Eminem this week demanded Republican presidential candidate Vivek Ramaswamy stop playing Lose Yourself on the campaign trail. Here are 10 other instances politicians have gotten the cold shoulder from artists they admired.

title.children: 'Moronic charade of a campaign': Ten times musicians told politicians to quit playing their music

image.altText: Gloved hands hold a selection of vapes above a bin of multi-coloured objects.

items.synopsis: A state school on Queensland's Gold Coast turns away from its hardline stance on vaping, in favour of an educational approach that's now being shared with other schools.

title.children: This school abandoned automatic suspensions for vaping. Here's what happened

image.altText: A man wearing a wet purple tshirt stands in knee-deep water filled with tree branches in the street

items.synopsis: Video footage and photographs from the region around Idalia's landfall showed ocean waters washing over highways and neighbourhoods swamped by extensive flooding as residents inspected the damage.

title.children: 'All hell broke loose': Hurricane Idalia tore down houses and flooded neighbourhoods in Florida
